Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: sexual-explicit and non-sexual-explicit. A comment is considered sexual-explicit if it explicitly portrays sexual matters.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: President lied under oath about consensual sex...
Not the same thing as rape.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment explicitly mentions "consensual sex" and "rape", and thus is sexual-explicit.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Yea its your pals choppin heads off. Take em all and leave my country
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but does not portray sexual matters.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: It's horrible, isn't it?  It had blood coming out of its eyes.  Blood coming out of its wherever.  Terrible.
Negative Examples.explanation: The comment is violent but does not portray sexual matters.
This comment contains explicit language of sexual matters and should be considered sexual-explicit, althought the intent of the comment might differ.

Comment: "Racial profile" covers a lot of ground and can be especially problematic here.  We locals tend to think we can figure out a person's racial/ethnic background just by looking at them, but it's far from that simple.  Could you tell a Laotian from a Vietnamese or a Cambodian?  Or what about a Pilipino with Chinese blood?  What about the different Polynesians, can you tell a Fijian from a Chuukese or a Tongan from a Samoan?

If you can't tell at a glance just walking down the street, how about a victim being able to tell at nighttime while in an extremely stressful situation?  So what do you do -- say "Oriental" or "Polynesian" or "Caucasian"?  Like that's gonna be a big help narrowing down the search here in Hawaii, especially if the person is "hapa" and looks like a little of each.  We end up looking side-eye at anyone who matches the "racial profile", and that becomes a problem.

Comment: I HATE that Trump was elected, but apparently you don't understand how the electoral college works. 

There are 538 electors from the 50 states. That number is based on the number of Representatives for each state (435 total based on state population) + 2 for the 2 senators for each state + 3 for DC. In most states, a electoral college voter CANNOT vote "against the state majority" (even if the "majority" is only 51% - which means essentially 49% of the state's votes "didn't count") without repercussions (in some states civil, in others criminal). That's how a candidate can win the popular vote and still lose the election - and the electoral college voters have very little choice (although the Constitution doesn't "bind" them to casting ALL votes the same as the popular majority for that state, the STATES DO).

Comment: "But I am inferring from your exposition of Breitbart's Jewish connection that you don't perceive them as racist."

I'll put it this way.  I'm not a fan of Benjamin Netanyahu. He's unabashedly right wing, authoritarian, nationalist to the point of being Zionist, and could arguably be called a racist because of the latter.  He sometimes plays fast and loose with laws, tends to be autocratic, and has to be reined in by the Knesset and Israeli courts on occasion.  Despite all that, know what I wouldn't call him?  A Nazi or neo-Nazi.

In fact, I wouldn't even call him a fascist, even though many do.  He's currently negotiating for his coalition government, and has done so without incident several times in the past. He's never tried to overthrow the Knesset and make a one party state, and has taken lost elections in stride. He's never tried to collect all the power in government into his own chair. RW =/= fascist, even if they are nationalists.

That's also how I see Breitbart.

Comment: Once again, as in June, homeowners’ replacement cost (4.1%) made the largest contribution to the annual CPI inflation rate. Ostensibly an index of new dwelling prices, the July annual change actually reflects the annual change for June 2017, since the new housing price data on which it is based can only be incorporated with a lag. So the discrepancy between the housing price increases shown between this series and the Teranet National Bank HPI is staggering: it shows an annual increase of 14.2% for June. It can’t be explained by the replacement cost index incorporating changes in VAT since if this were done properly (not that it is) this would tend to make the replacement cost series show higher rates of inflation, the effective VAT rates going up due to rising house prices even when the rates themselves stay the same.

Comment: Rik... man, you really have a stick up your arse don't you? First off, the dams were ancient, and unless you wanted to spend millions more to repair them only to repair them again in another few years, it was best to take them down. Second, the habitat gained by removal has, amazing as it might seem to you, been used by salmon, and used quite extensively. In fact, not only have they traveled deep into the park, but they have spawned, quite successfully in fact, throughout the river and tributaries opened up by dam removal. Salmon, as it turns out, are a very real source of income for thousands of fisherman across the state, and up in Alaska...

Comment: Technically, you are correct in that Premier Two Moms approval could be 0% but if voters decide to hold their noses and vote Liberal regardless then they would win.

Historically, however, you are decidedly out to lunch.  

Usually, there is a strong correlation between the approval rating % for the party leader and the vote % the party winds up receiving.

With 3 relatively strong major parties in Ontario, it is possible for one to win a majority with 36-39% of the vote.

But no party can win a majority or even a minority if they stand at 16% in the polls and no party whose leader at election time stands at 16% in the polls will pull more than 24-25% of the vote (usually within 5 points of 16%).

If you have a persuasive argument otherwise, I would be fascinated to hear it.

P.S.  Take her greater public sector supporters out of the equation and Wynne-Bag is now at about 10% .   And we could be even worse off is the NDP aka The Notoriously Dumb Party takes the trougher vote and wins

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Thanks for an insightful column, Tim  Egan.
For those of us who grew up as kids during WWII, the sight of Americans marching through Charlottesville waving Nazi (and KKK) symbols was horrifying.  It's sad  to think what our old WWII Vets must  be wondering--  did they and their buddies fight and die  "to make America safe for Nazis?"
Growing up I learned to hate Germans and Naziism (which seemed synonymous  to me) so later when the USASA sent me to Germany just 14 years after that terrible war I wasn't happy.  And yet,  I found most  of the Germans I got to know--including "Papi" my future father in law, a 6-year Wehrmacht vet- were very good people.  The problem was Naziism, not Germans.  
This led me to my biggest Life question-- how could such good people have done such horrible things?  How did a well-educated democracy end up choosing fascism?
Now as I watch the growth of Neo-Nazism here I'm getting my answer-- and it's ugly.

Comment: "Truth and facts are not hate speech."

Yet as you pointed out, the truth doesn't belong to you. So what is it, exactly, that you're offering?

It's trivially correct that truth and facts alone can't be hate speech. It's also true that the best propaganda always contains facts. What propaganda doesn't do is give ALL the facts, presented in a balanced way. Hate speech does the same thing. It hammers on the faults of a group- which are typically the same ones you can say of any group- over and over. After a relentless barrage of selectively chosen negatives comes the kicker: "We have to push back. If we don't, we're done for."

I could write you a litany of facts about Western Christians that would whiten your hair. And if that's all you ever heard, you would come to fear Western Christians. From that point, encouraging you to act against them would be easy.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Recall that the US came pretty close to losing the War of 1812.

So his use of the "land of the free" absolutely excluded blacks and the anthem does celebrate their deaths.

Comment: United used to be a decent airline. In October 2010, they merged with Continental which had always, in my experience, been a horrible airline. We were flying back from New England when Continental-uniformed staff stepped into United Airlines jobs and immediately the customer service took a nose-dive. I filed a complaint for the way they treated my mother-in-law for just being a little slow to respond to them. That was the same weekend the TSA started the nude photoscanning and pat down searches, so it was a miserable trip home and we're still waiting to hear back on that complaint.

I wasn't surprised to see this in the news. Arrogance will always show in a company eventually. That their own crew had priority over a passenger makes me wonder if United's CEOs and middle managers need to take a course on capitalism.

Back of this may be a government regulation about flight crew transport. Many business problems trace back to government rules forcing impossible choices.

Comment: The problem is the Wild Card. With 2 wild card spots, by the July 31 trade deadline every season there may only be 2-3 teams that are actually out of it. So everyone else is a "contender" to make a WC and possibly play a single playoff game. Meanwhile, serious teams like the Dodgers, Red Sox, Cubs, and Yankees build teams with a goal of winning not just a Wild Card, but the World Series. Anything less than a World Series title is failure. Eliminate the Wild Card. Add a team to each league. Form 4 Divisions in each and you will get more teams forced to spend money to build REAL teams.  Unfortunately the current system supports mediocrity and keeps fans interested and in the stands. Sadly it will never happen. Shapiro has no intention of building a World Series winning team. He is satisfied to shoot for the WC and hope for the best. And the fans are suckers.

Comment: Like I pointed out, my first house was a starter house, and based on the pictures on zillow, still is.  Small, crappy, not great neighborhood, but the estimate is almost 400k for it.  As someone who was working a crappy paying blue collar job at the time, I can attest to how hard it was to save the 26k we needed for a downpayment.  I'm not sure that were I in that job today, even making more, based on going pay rates, that I would have been able to buy anything that didn't involve a monster of a commute.  That commute also has associated costs, especially since our transit system here, kinda sucks.

As I said, I think that people do need to take a hard look at the fact that housing has gone up at 3 or 4x the rate of wage growth, before just writing off millennials as whiners.  I find that they whine about many things that are just how things have always been, but in this case, I'm not sure their whining isn't entirely accurate.

Comment: Everyone should pause and think about war for a minute. Maybe check out some of the images coming from Syria. An estimated 11 million Syrians have been displaced from their homes and unable to return since the start of that conflict. About 2.6 million of those affected are children who no longer have the option of going to school. About 2 million of these children are living as refugees in neighboring countries. Is this the future you want for your friends and neighbors? I know a lot of us think we are "prepared," and will be able to "fight off the hordes" and fend for ourselves. This is a fantasy. When the dogs of war slip their chain, they indiscriminately leave death and destruction in their wake. I've seen this. Do you really think whatever political philosophy you espouse, and this insane black or white and growing cultural divide we have developed is worth that?
